FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a First-class or charter travel
ExplntnTxt: The University does not pay the cost of first class travel. Any exceptions to this policy require the written approval of the President or Vice President for Business & Finance, obtained in advance of travel. Employees are permitted to use personal airline miles, "points," or other for upgrades; however, the University will not reimburse employees for the value of these upgrades. During the calendar year 2018 there was one exception granted to approve one-time first class travel. In addition, another employee with a high public profile is allowed to fly first class on all trips in order to minimize social interactions in coach, as per his employee contract. The value of the first class travel was considered a necessary business expense and therefore, was not included on the W2 for these employees.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Travel for companions
ExplntnTxt: Companion travel is the financial responsibility of the traveler except in cases where the presence of the companion is required for university business reasons and therefore is not included in the individual's W-2.

ExplntnTxt: GW OFFERED AN ANNUAL INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PLAN FOR CERTAIN SENIOR OFFICIALS. THE ANNUAL AWARD OPPORTUNITY IS CAPPED AT A PERCENTAGE OF THEIR SALARY. THE PLAN INCLUDES PROGRAMMATIC GOALS AND OBJECTIVES FOR THE YEAR THAT ARE SPECIFIC TO THEIR DEPARTMENT OR DIVISION GOALS. REVIEW OF COMPENSATION OF CEO, OFFICER, OR KEY EMPLOYEES: THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD REVIEWS THE SALARY OF THE PRESIDENT EACH YEAR. THEY BENCHMARK TOTAL COMPENSATION TO OTHER ATS PEER SCHOOLS THAT ARE THE SAME APPROXIMATE SIZE AND OFFERING THE SAME DEGREES. THE SEMINARY PROVIDES THE SAME BENEFIT STRUCTURE TO ALL EMPLOYEES. EXECUTIVE OFFICERS DO NOT QUALIFY FOR SPECIAL BENEFITS NOT OFFERED TO THE GENERAL EMPLOYED COMMUNITY. THE REVIEWS ARE GENERALLY DISCUSSED THROUGH CONFERENCE CALLS WITH THE INDIVIDUALS DESCRIBED ABOVE. LETTERS OF CALL ARE PREPARED AND DOCUMENTED IN EACH PERSON'S PERSONNEL FILE IN THE HUMAN RESOURCE OFFICE. PTS HAS ALSO DEVELOPED A PAY GRADE SCALE FOR ALL POSITIONS WITHIN THE INSTITUTION. THIS WAS DEVELOPED AND COMPILED WITH THE HELP OF AN OUTSIDE CONSULTANT WHO TOOK INTO ACCOUNT AREA MARKET DATA ALONG WITH ATS COMPARABLE DATA.

DURING THE CALENDAR YEAR 2019, COMPENSATION FOR THE TOP MANAGEMENT OFFICIAL WAS ESTABLISHED AND PAID BY COMMONSPIRIT HEALTH, A RELATED ORGANIZATION. COMMONSPIRIT HEALTH USED THE FOLLOWING TO ESTABLISH THE TOP MANAGEMENT OFFICIAL'S COMPENSATION: (1) COMPENSATION COMMITTEE; (2) INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT; (3) COMPENSATION SURVEY OR STUDY; (4) APPROVAL BY THE BOARD OR COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. COMPENSATION FOR THE OTHER OFFICERS OF ALEGENT CREIGHTON HEALTH WAS ESTABLISHED BY THE CHI HEALTH CEO AND HUMAN RESOURCES DIRECTOR USING THE FOLLOWING METHODS TO ESTABLISH THE COMPENSATION: (1) COMPENSATION SURVEYS OR STUDIES (2) INDEPENDENT COMPENSATION CONSULTANT AND (3) APPROVAL BY THE BOARD COMPENSATION COMMITTEE.

SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 4A - SEVERANCE OR CHANGE-OF-CONTROL PAYMENTS: FOR REPORTABLE INDIVIDUALS EMPLOYED PRIOR TO 2019, POST-TERMINATION PAYMENTS ARE ADDRESSED IN EXECUTIVE EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENTS FOR EMPLOYEES AT THE LEVEL OF VICE PRESIDENT AND ABOVE. THESE EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENTS REQUIRE THAT IN ORDER FOR THE EXECUTIVE TO RECEIVE POST-TERMINATION PAYMENTS, THESE INDIVIDUALS MUST EXECUTE A GENERAL RELEASE AND SETTLEMENT AGREEMENT. POST-TERMINATION PAYMENT ARRANGEMENTS ARE PERIODICALLY REVIEWED FOR OVERALL REASONABLENESS IN LIGHT OF THE EXECUTIVE'S OVERALL COMPENSATION PACKAGE. OFFICERS, KEY EMPLOYEES AND CERTAIN HIGHLY COMPENSATED EMPLOYEES WHO BEGAN EMPLOYMENT AFTER NOVEMBER 1ST OF 2019 ARE COVERED BY A SEVERANCE POLICY THAT PROVIDES MARKET-STANDARD COMPENSATION, RANGING FROM PAYMENTS OF 9 MONTHS TO 2 YEARS OF BASE COMPENSATION, DEPENDING ON THE EXECUTIVE'S POSITION, IN THE EVENT OF A POSITION ELIMINATION OR OTHER INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION, IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE GUIDELINES OF THE POLICY. THE FOLLOWING REPORTABLE INDIVIDUALS RECEIVED SEVERANCE PAYMENTS FROM ALEGENT CREIGHTON HEALTH DURING THE 2019 CALENDAR YEAR, AND THESE SEVERANCE PAYMENTS WERE INCLUDED IN THE INDIVIDUALS' W-2 INCOME AND REPORTABLE COMPENSATION ON PART VII AND SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(III): NANCY WALLACE, $188,001. SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 4B - SUPPLEMENTAL NONQUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN: DURING THE 2019 CALENDAR YEAR, COMMONSPIRIT MAINTAINED A SUPPLEMENTAL NON-QUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN FOR DIVISION CEOS/HOSPITAL PRESIDENTS AND OTHER DESIGNATED COMMONSPIRIT EXECUTIVES AT THE LEVEL OF SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT AND ABOVE. DURING 2019 THE FOLLOWING DISTRIBUTIONS WERE MADE BY COMMONSPIRIT FROM THE DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN: CLIFF ROBERTSON, $139,927; JEANETTE WOJTALEWICZ, $62,916; ANN SCHUMACHER, $19,322; KEVIN MILLER, $10,346; GREGORY BECKMANN, $7,023; AND DEREK VANCE, $3,018. DUE TO THE "SUPER" VESTING RULES UNDER COMMONSPIRIT'S DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN, PARTICIPANTS WHO HAVE MET CERTAIN REQUIREMENTS SUCH AS INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION WITHOUT CAUSE, AGE, AGE AND YEARS OF SERVICE, OR MORE THAN 5 YEARS OF PLAN PARTICIPATION ARE ELIGIBLE TO RECEIVE THEIR 2019 CONTRIBUTIONS IN CASH. THESE CASH PAYOUTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE PARTICIPANT'S REPORTABLE COMPENSATION IN COLUMN (III) OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION ON SCHEDULE J PART II. INCLUDE IF APPLICABLE: DURING 2019, THE FOLLOWING PAYMENTS WERE MADE PURSUANT TO THE SUPER VESTING RULES: CLIFF ROBERTSON, $182,082; JEANETTE WOJTALEWICZ, $57,305; KATHY BRESSLER, $53,648; MICHAEL SCHNIEDERS, $21,369; AND MARIE KNEDLER, $3,770.

DURING THE 2019 CALENDAR YEAR, COMMONSPIRIT MAINTAINED A VARIABLE PAY PROGRAM FOR MANAGERS AND ABOVE THAT PUTS A CERTAIN AMOUNT OF COMPENSATION AT RISK. AWARDS OF INCENTIVE COMPENSATION UNDER THE VARIABLE PAY PROGRAM ARE MADE BASED UPON ACHIEVEMENT OF ORGANIZATIONAL OBJECTIVES INCLUDING FINANCIAL OUTCOMES, QUALITY IMPROVEMENT, AND OTHER MEASURES AS DETERMINED ANNUALLY BY THE HR COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF STEWARDSHIP TRUSTEES. HOWEVER, ELIGIBLE AWARDS PAYABLE UNDER THIS PROGRAM ARE DEPENDENT ON REACHING MINIMUM LEVELS OF OPERATING MARGIN AND CHARITY CARE LEVELS, UNLESS THE HR COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF STEWARDSHIP TRUSTEES USES ITS DISCRETION TO APPROVE AN EXCEPTION. SUCH EXCEPTIONS ARE NOT APPLIED TO INDIVIDUALS OR CLASSES OF INDIVIDUALS, BUT RATHER TO THE PROGRAM AS A WHOLE.

IRS INSTRUCTIONS TO FORM 990 REQUIRE THAT THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF HOUSING PROVIDED TO EMPLOYEES BY THEIR EMPLOYERS BE REPORTED ON FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II. AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY IS REQUIRED TO RESIDE ON CAMPUS PREMISES. THE RESIDENCE SERVES BOTH AS A PERSONAL RESIDENCE AS WELL AS A VENUE FOR CARRYING OUT UNIVERSITY BUSINESS. THE UNIVERSITY HAS DETERMINED THAT THE VALUE OF THE USE OF THE PERSONAL RESIDENCE IS NOT CONSIDERED TAXABLE INCOME TO THE PRESIDENT AS PROVIDED IN INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 119. FOR TAX YEAR 2019, THE PRESIDENT'S USE OF THE RESIDENCE IS CONSERVATIVELY ESTIMATED AT $42,000. THIS ESTIMATED VALUE IS BASED ON A FAIR RENTAL VALUE OF $3,500 PER MONTH FOR SIMILAR HOUSES IN THE AREA. THIS VALUE INCLUDES MAINTENANCE OF THE PROPERTY, LANDSCAPING, AND SNOW REMOVAL.

TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS UP PAYMENTS - COMPENSATION FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OFFICER WAS GROSSED UP FOR THE PERSONAL USE OF A CORPORATE VEHICLE. THE AMOUNT IS INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S TAXABLE INCOME. HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES - THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY UTILIZES THE MEMBERSHIP FOR BUSINESS PURPOSES. NOT INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE INCOME SINCE THE USE IS BUSINESS RELATED. PERSONAL SERVICES - THE PRESIDENT IS PROVIDED WITH CLEANING SERVICES AND CATERING FOR UNIVERSITY RELATED EVENTS. THE BUSINESS PORTION IS NOT TAXABLE WITH ANY PERSONAL PORTION BEING INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE INCOME. REIMBURSEMENTS/PAYMENTS ARE NOT ALLOWED FOR ITEMS LISTED EXCEPT FOR THE PRESIDENT. THE SPECIFIC ITEMS CHECKED ARE ADDRESSED IN THE PRESIDENT'S CONTRACT.
FRED OHLES PARTICIPATED IN A 457(F) PLAN. FOR THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED MAY 31, 2019, NEBRASKA WESLEYAN UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTED $20,000 TO THE PLAN.

SPOUSAL TRAVEL OCCURS IN VERY LIMITED CIRMCUMSTANCES FOR THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT AND SR VICE PRESIDENT OF UNIVERSITY ADVANCEMENT WHEN ATTENDING UNIVERSITY RELATED EVENTS AND FUNCTIONS. UNIVERSITY POLICY REQUIRES PRE-APPROVAL BY THE BOARD CHAIR AND WRITTEN SUBSTANTIATION OF THE BONA FIDE BUSINES PURPOSE WHEN ACCOMPANIED BY A SPOUSE. SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE EMPLOYEE AS REQUIRED BY THE IRS WHEN IT IS NOT FOR A BONA FIDE UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSE. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES REVIEWS TRAVEL DOCUMENTATION. THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT RECEIVES AN ANNUAL HOUSING ALLOWANCE PURSUANT TO HIS EXECUTIVE CONTRACT. ALL HOUSING ALLOWANCE AMOUNTS ARE INCLUDED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION ON FORM W-2 AND REPORTED IN PART II, COLUMN (B)(III). THE PRESIDENT IS REIMBURSED FOR AN ANNUAL CREDIT CARD MEMBERSHIP FEE WHICH IS PROVIDED SOLELY FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS RELATED TRAVEL. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT PROVIDE PAYMENT FOR PERSONAL SERVICES, TAX INDEMNIFICATIONS OR GROSS-UP PAYMENTS FOR ANY PERSON LISTED IN PART VII, SECTION A.

THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES COMPENSATION COMMITTEE IS RESPONSIBLE FOR MAKING RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE CONCERNING COMPENSATION OF THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT, AND SETTING COMPENSATION AND OTHER TERMS AND CONDITIONS OF EMPLOYMENT FOR OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE PROCESS FOR DETERMINING COMPENSATION INCLUDES RETAINING AN INDEPENDENT FIRM TRIENIALLY TO STUDY EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION TO ASSURE THAT THE COMPENSATION OF EACH OFFICER IS COMPARABLE TO POSITIONS OF SIMILARLY SITUATED ORGANIZATIONS. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE IS ALSO RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING OR COMMISSIONING ANY OTHER NECESSARY SURVEY OR STUDIES AND REPORT THE RESULTS TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. MEETINGS AND DECISIONS OF THIS COMMITTEE ARE DOCUMENTED CONTEMPORANEOUSLY IN COMMITTEE MINUTES.
GREG HERENDA, HEAD COACH MEN'S BASKETBALL RECEIVED A $55,750. PERFORMANCE BONUS PURSUANT TO HIS CONTRACT.

THE PRESIDENT RESIDES IN UNIVERSITY-OWNED HOUSING, WHICH IS ON THE SOUTH CAMPUS. BY LOCATING HER IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO THE UNIVERSITY, IT HELPS TO MAKE THE PRESIDENT AVAILABLE FOR THE DAILY INTERACTION BETWEEN THE COMMUNITY AND THE UNIVERSITY STAFF/STUDENTS/ALUMNI/DONORS AND PHYSICAL PLANTS. THE UNIVERSITY-PROVIDED HOUSING IS GEOGRAPHICALLY INTEGRATED WITH THE UNIVERSITY'S EDUCATIONAL PROPERTY. THE PRESIDENT PERFORMS MANY UNIVERSITY TASKS AND FUNCTIONS AT THE RESIDENCE. THE RESIDENCE IS FURNISHED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY AND IS REQUIRED TO BE OCCUPIED BY THE PRESIDENT AS A CONDITION OF HER EMPLOYMENT. AS THE UNIVERSITY'S PRINCIPAL FUND-RAISER, THE PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS ACTUAL OR POTENTIAL BENEFACTORS, VISITING DIGNITARIES AND COMMUNITY LEADERS IN THE RESIDENCE. THE HEAVINESS OF THE PRESIDENT'S ADMINISTRATIVE WORKLOAD, THE PRESENCE OF UNIVERSITY-RELATED SOCIAL FUNCTIONS AND THE NUMBER OF CONFERENCES SCHEDULED WITH STUDENTS OR FACULTY MEMBERS REQUIRE ACCESS TO THE MAJORITY OF THE RESIDENCE. IN ADDITION, THE UNIVERSITY CONDUCTS OTHER EVENTS THAT ARE ESSENTIAL TO ITS EDUCATIONAL EXEMPTION. IN LIEU OF THE AFOREMENTIONED INTRICACIES OF MULTIPLE USES BY MANY MULTIPLE PARTIES INVOLVED, IT IS IMPRACTICAL AND WOULD NOT BE CONSIDERED AN ACCURATE CALCULATION OF THE FAIR MARKET VALUE OF QUALIFIED CAMPUS LODGING FURNISHED TO THE PRESIDENT. DUE TO THESE FACTORS, THE UNIVERSITY HAS DECIDED TO OMIT ENTERING THE ESTIMATED AMOUNT OF TAX FREE HOUSING ALLOWANCE PROVIDED IN COLUMN F OF FORM 990, PART VII, SECTION A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN D - "NONTAXABLE BENEFITS". THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES A HOUSE CLEANER FOR THE PRESIDENT AND ALSO PERFORMS ALL NECESSARY MAINTENANCE ON THE HOME.
BRETT BARGER - $158,147

THE ORGANIZATION'S CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER/TOP MANAGEMENT OFFICIAL IS PAID BY ITS RELATED ORGANIZATION, PROVIDENCE HEALTH & SERVICES WASHINGTON, AND IS DISCLOSED AS A PERSON PAID BY A RELATED ORGANIZATION. SEE SCHEDULE O, PART VI, LINE 15A FOR THE PROCESS USED BY PROVIDENCE HEALTH & SERVICES WASHINGTON.

BEGINNING IN JULY 2015, NEW EXECUTIVES PARTICIPATE IN A NON-QUALIFIED SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN. THE PLAN PROVIDES FOR EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS BASED ON A PERCENTAGE OF EXECUTIVE BASE SALARY AND ARE SUBJECT TO A FIVE YEAR OR AGE 65 VESTING SCHEDULE. CERTAIN EXECUTIVES PARTICIPATE IN A NON-QUALIFIED SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN PROVIDED BY A RELATED ENTITY. THE AMOUNTS SHOWN IN COLUMN F OF PART II REFLECT CURRENT YEAR PAYOUTS FROM THESE PLANS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II - EXECUTIVE INCENTIVE PROGRAM
ExplntnTxt: UNIVERSITY OF PROVIDENCE EXECUTIVES PARTICIPATE IN THE PROVIDENCE EXECUTIVE INCENTIVE PROGRAM WHICH PROVIDES A LUMP SUM AWARD ANNUALLY AS A PERCENT OF THE EXECUTIVE'S BASE PAY. PERCENT OPPORTUNITIES ARE ALIGNED WITH OUR TOTAL COMPENSATION PHILOSOPHY AS OUTLINED IN PART VI, SECTION B, LINE 15 (PROCESS FOR DETERMINING COMPENSATION OF TOP MANAGEMENT, OFFICERS & KEY EMPLOYEES). THE PERFORMANCE AWARD IS BASED ON THE LEVEL OF ACCOMPLISHMENT OF ANNUAL SYSTEM AND FUNCTIONAL (OR REGIONAL) OBJECTIVES. IN 2017, 60 PERCENT OF THE PARTICIPANT AWARDS WERE BASED ON PRE-DETERMINED ORGANIZATIONAL GOALS CONSISTENT WITH PROVIDENCE'S STRATEGIC PRIORITIES. THE REMAINING 40% WAS BASED ON A ROBUST SET OF FUNCTION SPECIFIC GOALS DESIGNED TO ALIGN CRITICAL MISSION AND BUSINESS DRIVERS. IN 2018 THE PERCENT ALLOCATION FOR EACH OF THESE STRATEGIC PRIORITIES WAS AS OUTLINED BELOW: SYSTEM GOALS: FIRST-YEAR TURNOVER - 10% INPATIENT EXPERIENCE - 5% PATIENT EXPERIENCE - 5% MEDICAL GROUP PATIENT EXPERIENCE - 5% COMMUNITY BENEFIT - 10% CLINICAL EXCELLENCE - 15% FREE CASH FLOW - 10%

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 1a Housing allowance or residence for personal use
ExplntnTxt: THE ORGANIZATION PROVIDED HOUSING FOR THE FORMER PRESIDENT UNTIL HIS TERM ENDED ON 5/31/2019. AS AGREED UPON IN HIS CONTRACT, THE COLLEGE REQUIRED THE PRESIDENT TO MAINTAIN A RESIDENCE ON CAMPUS. AS SUCH, THE COLLEGE CONSIDERED THIS TO BE FOR BUSINESS USE AND WAS NOT TAXABLE TO THE FORMER PRESIDENT. EFFECTIVE 08/01/2019, THE COLLEGE NO LONGER REQUIRES THE PRESIDENT TO MAINTAIN RESIDENCE ON CAMPUS. THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION PACKAGE INCLUDES A TAXABLE HOUSING ALLOWANCE.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS A MEMBERSHIP IN A LOCAL SOCIAL CLUB THAT IS IN THE PRESIDENT'S NAME WHICH IS FOR THE PURPOSE OF HELPING PROMOTE AND CONDUCT BUSINESS ON BEHALF OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIP IS USED 100 PERCENT FOR BUSINESS AND THE PRESIDENT USES THE ACCOUNTABLE PLAN RULES FOR DOCUMENTING THE BUSINESS USE. SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 4B THE UNIVERSITY CURRENTLY HAS A 457(F) DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN IN PLACE WITH THE UNIVERSITYS PRESIDENT WHEREBY THE UNIVERSITY MAKES AN ANNUAL CONTRIBUTION INTO THE PLAN WHERE THE FUNDS ARE INVESTED IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PLAN GUIDELINES. FOR FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2020, THE UNIVERSITY CONTRIBUTED $100,000 INTO THE PLAN. THE PLAN CURRENTLY PROVIDES THAT IF THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT REMAINS EMPLOYED BY THE UNIVERSITY FOR THREE YEARS AND ACHIEVES CERTAIN OBJECTIVES, THE BALANCE IN THE PLAN AT THE END OF SUCH THREE YEAR PERIOD VESTS AND IS PAID TO THE UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT AT THAT TIME. IN JUNE 2019, THE THREE-YEAR VESTING PERIOD FROM JULY 1, 2016 JUNE 30, 2019 WAS COMPLETED AND A PAYMENT OF $298,872 WAS PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT FROM THE PLAN REPRESENTING THE ACCMULATED BALANCE IN THE PLAN FOR THAT THREE-YEAR PERIOD. THIS AMOUNT IS INCLUDED ON THE PRESIDENTS CALENDAR YEAR 2019 W-2 AND IS RECORDED IN PART II, COLUMN (B)(III) ON SCHEDULE J. SCHEDULE J, PART II, LINE 2 & 3, COLUMN I & II, COMPENSATION AND BONUS TO RETAIN TALENT WITHIN THE UNIVERSITYS EXECUTIVE TEAM, THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES APPROVES RETENTION CONTRACTS FOR CERTAIN OFFICERS. THE CONTRACTS STATE IF THE OFFICER MEETS AGREED UPON OBJECTIVES AND IS STILL WORKING WITH THE UNIVERSITY AT THE END OF A THREE YEAR PERIOD, A RETENTION BONUS IS PAID. DURING CALENDAR YEAR 2019, RETENTION BONUSES WERE PAID TO AARTI DHUPELIA AND ALISON HILSABECK IN THE AMOUNTS OF $75,000 AND $75,000, RESPECTIVELY, FOR SERVICES PERFORMED OVER FISCAL YEARS 2017-2019. THESE PAYMENTS ARE INCLUDED ON THE OFFICERS CALENDAR YEAR 2019 W-2 AND RECORDED IN PART II, COLUMN (B)(ii) ON SCHEDULE J. In JULY 2019, RETENTION CONTRACTS WERE APPROVED FOR AARTI DHUPELIA AND MARTY MICKEY FOR THE UPCOMING THREE-YEAR PERIOD. IN CONNECTION THEREWITH, THESE OFFICERS WILL EARN $75,000 AT THE END OF THE THREE YEAR PERIOD (JUNE 30, 2022), IF THEY ACHIEVE THE OBJECTIVES UNDER THE PLAN.

FOR THE CURRENT REPORTING PERIOD THE USAGE OF THE COUNTRY CLUB MEMBERSHIP WAS FOR BUSINESS USE ONLY AND IS THEREFORE NOT TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO ANY EMPLOYEE. THE UNIVERSITY FOLLOWED ITS GENERAL EXPENSE POLICY FOR THESE EXPENSES, WHICH REQUIRES RECEIPT DOCUMENTATION TO BE PROVIDED PROVING THE BUSINESS PURPOSE FOR THE USE.

THE PRESIDENT WAS PROVIDED A MEMBERSHIP AT A LOCAL COUNTRY CLUB TO BE USED FOR FUNDRAISING ACTIVITIES AND OTHER COLLEGE BUSINESS. USE OF THE MEMBERSHIP IS SUBSTANTIATED. LASTLY, THE COLLEGE PROVIDES HOUSING AND WEEKLY HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES TO THE PRESIDENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER SO THAT THE PRESIDENT CAN PERFORM ESSENTIAL COLLEGE BUSINESS AND ACTIVITIES AT THE HOME. BOTH BENEFITS SERVE A BUSINESS PURPOSE OF THE COLLEGE AND THEREFORE ARE NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE.
JOSHUA MERCHANT, PRESIDENT OF BUENA VISTA UNIVERSITY, IS PROVIDED HOUSING THAT MEETS THE EXCLUSION UNDER SECTION 119 AND THEREFORE IS NOT INCLUDED IN TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE THE PRESIDENT OF WASHINGTON COLLEGE IS PROVIDED HOUSING AS A CONDITION OF HIS/HER EMPLOYMENT. A HOUSE IS PROVIDED ON CAMPUS FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE COLLEGE TO ENABLE THE PRESIDENT TO RESPOND TO EMERGENT SITUATIONS 24/7. HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES THE PRESIDENT OF WASHINGTON COLLEGE IS REIMBURSED THE COST OF SOCIAL CLUB DUES. TO THE EXTENT THAT THE PRESIDENT USES THE CLUB FOR PERSONAL PURPOSES, THE VALUE OF THE BENEFIT IS INCLUDED IN HIS/HER TAXABLE INCOME. PERSONAL SERVICES THE PRESIDENT OF THE COLLEGE RECEIVED NOMINAL HOUSEKEEPING AND CHAUFFER SERVICES. THE PERSONAL SERVICES ARE PROVIDED AS A BUSINESS NEED. HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES ARE FOR CLEANING THE COMMON AREAS USED FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS ONLY. THE CHAUFFER SERVICES ARE PROVIDED ONLY DURING BUSINESS HOURS TO ALLOW THE PRESIDENT TO WORK ELECTRONICALLY WHILE TRAVELING, THOUGH SUCH INSTANCES ARE NOT COMMON.

FIRST-CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL - THE MEN'S BASKETBALL COACH OCCASIONALLY TRAVELS WITH HIS TEAM BY MEANS OF CHARTER TRAVEL FOR SCHEDULED COMPETITIONS. THE VALUE IS NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. PART I, LINE 1B: THE PROVISION OF NON-STANDARD BENEFITS IS DETERMINED BY THE PRESIDENT, FOR SENIOR LEADERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES, AND THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, FOR THE PRESIDENT. FACTORS CONSIDERED ARE WHETHER THE BENEFIT UNDER CONSIDERATION IS COMMONLY PROVIDED TO INDIVIDUALS IN SIMILAR POSITIONS AT SIMILAR ORGANIZATIONS; WHETHER THE BENEFIT IS NECESSARY FOR THE INDIVIDUAL TO SUCCESSFULLY FULFILL HIS OR HER JOB RESPONSIBILITIES; AND WHETHER, IN THE CONTEXT OF THE INDIVIDUAL'S OVERALL COMPENSATION, THE PROVISION OF THE NON-STANDARD BENEFIT IS REASONABLE.

As a condition of employment Middlebury provides the President, an officer, with a residence for the convenience of the employer. Part I, Line 7: The President's compensation is set by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees. Any increases shall be within the Board's sole discretion and shall be based upon the President's performance, which will be reviewed yearly, prior to June 30 by the Chair of the Board, who will make a recommendation to the Compensation Committee for compensation. Part I, Line 8: The President's employment contract includes provisions governing the following: term of the contract, renewal/extension, duties, compensation, benefits/reimbursements, evaluation process of the president, termination, office and residence expenses, and sabbatical leave.

The Provost participates in a supplemental nonqualified retirement plan which is contingent upon services. Deferred compensation includes pretax contributions to the voluntary retirement plan, contributions to Middlebury's non-qualified tax advantaged deferred-compensation retirement plan (457 plan), and Middlebury contributions to the core retirement plan on the behalf of the employee. Three individuals reported in Schedule J, Part II, received payments related to contractual obligations, which are reported in Schedule J, Part II, column B (iii). FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PAGE 1, PART I, LINE 1A
ExplntnTxt: UNDER IRC SECT 119(A) THE VALUE OF LODGING PROVIDED IN-KIND TO AN EMPLOYEE (THE PRESIDENT) FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE EMPLOYER IS EXCLUDABLE FROM GROSS INCOME IF THE EMPLOYEE IS REQUIRED TO ACCEPT SUCH LODGING ON THE BUSINESS PREMISES OF THE EMPLOYER AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT. THE COLLEGE REQUIRES AND FURNISHES A HOME FOR THE PRESIDENT'S USE AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT. THE PRESIDENT IS TO USE THE HOME TO ENTERTAIN OR HOLD MEETINGS FOR BOARD MEMBERS, VARIOUS COLLEGE EMPLOYEES, POTENTIAL DONORS, AND STUDENTS. THIS IS A SCHOOL POLICY AND IS PART OF HIS EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT. THE PRESIDENT HAS USED THE RESIDENCE EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS. HE HAS AN OFFICE IN THE HOUSE SOLELY DESIGNATED FOR COLLEGE WORK THAT HE USES EACH DAY AND ON WEEKENDS. THE PRESIDENT ENTERTAINS THE TRUSTEES WHICH DROP BY CONTINUOUSLY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR. THE PRESIDENT WILL HOLD CABINET MEETINGS AT THE HOUSE PERIODICALLY. MEETINGS WITH COMMUNITY OFFICIALS OCCUR FREQUENTLY AT THE HOUSE. THE PRESIDENT MEETS POTENTIAL AND LONG-TIME DONORS AT HIS HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH TO SECURE CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THE COLLEGE. HE HOLDS A FRESHMAN SEMINAR CLASS AT THE HOME SEVERAL TIMES A MONTH. THE PRESIDENT HAS ALSO ALLOWED STUDENTS TO STAY AT THE HOUSE FOR SHORT STAYS WHEN NEEDED. HIS HOME IS ALWAYS OPEN TO STUDENTS TO DROP BY AND VISIT. THE PRESIDENT PERFORMS A MEANINGFUL PORTION OF HIS DUTIES AT HIS HOME. THE COLLEGE PAYS FOR THE PRESIDENT'S ANNUAL MEMBERSHIP TO THE MCPHERSON COUNTRY CLUB. THIS AMOUNT IS TREATED AS TAXABLE TO THE PRESIDENT AND INCLUDED IN WAGES.

HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE THE PRESIDENT, MARYLOU YAM, IS PROVIDED UNIVERSITY HOUSING AS A CONDITION OF HER EMPLOYMENT. HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES THE UNIVERSITY PAYS THE PRESIDENT'S AND VICE-PRESIDENT'S INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT'S DUES TO SOCIAL CLUBS. THE PRESIDENT AND THE VICE PRESIDENT FOR INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT USE THESE VENUES FOR BUSINESS MEETINGS AND ENTERTAINMENT OF DONORS. THE SOCIAL CLUB DUES ARE TREATED AS NON-TAXABLE.

THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION CONTRACT IS PREPARED USING AN INDEPENDENT CONSULTANT, COMPENSATION SURVEYS, AND THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES. AFTER APPROVAL BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, THE CONTRACT IS PRESENTED TO THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES FOR THEIR ANNUAL REVIEW AND APPROVAL. THE PRESIDENT'S CONTRACT IS REVIEWED ANNUALLY. MINUTES OF DELIBERATIONS ARE CONTEMPORANEOUSLY MAINTAINED.

THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF QUINNIPIAC UNIVERSITY FACILITATES THE EVALUATION PROCESS AND SALARY REVIEW OF THE PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE COMMITTEE MEETS ON A REGULAR BASIS AT LEAST TWO TIMES EACH YEAR TO EVALUATE THE PERFORMANCE OF THE PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENTS BASED ON THE SUCCESS OR FAILURE OF MEETING THEIR APPROVED ANNUAL GOALS AND OBJECTIVES. THEIR SALARY ADJUSTMENTS BASED ON MERIT ARE TIED TO THIS EVALUATION, COMPARATIVE SALARY DATA FROM SIMILIAR INSTITUTIONS AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE PRESIDENT OR, IN THE CASE OF THE PRESIDENT, THE COMMITTEE. THE COMMITTEE HAS AUTHORITY AS DELEGATED TO IT BY THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES TO EXECUTE AND AMEND THE CONTRACTS FOR THE PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY.

ELIGIBLE EXECUTIVES (GENERALLY VICE PRESIDENTS AND ABOVE) PARTICIPATE IN A PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES FOR SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT BENEFITS. THE PAYMENT OF BENEFITS UNDER THE PROGRAM, IF ANY, IS ENTIRELY DEPENDENT UPON THE FACTS AND CIRCUMSTANCES UNDER WHICH THE EXECUTIVE TERMINATES EMPLOYMENT WITH THE ORGANIZATION. PART I, LINE 7 AT RISK COMPENSATION (ARS) AWARD IS BASED ON THE ACHIEVEMENT OF AN OBJECTIVE AND QUANTITATIVE SET OF MEASURABLE GOALS WHICH ARE MUTUALLY ESTABLISHED BETWEEN THE PRESIDENT AND ELIGIBLE PARTICIPANTS AT THE BEGINNING OF EACH FISCAL YEAR. THE PRESIDENT MAKES HIS ASSESSMENT OF EACH PARTICIPANT'S ACHIEVEMENT OF SPECIFIC GOALS, AND PRESENTS HIS "AT RISK AWARD" RECOMMENDATION TO THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES FOR FINAL REVIEW AND APPROVAL.

PART II, COLUMN B (III) INCLUDES PAYMENTS FOR GROUP TERM LIFE PREMIUMS AND PERSONAL USE OF AUTO. IN 2003, AFTER RONALD K. MACHTLEY ("MACHTLEY") SERVED AS BRYANT'S PRESIDENT FOR SEVEN YEARS, BRYANT'S BOARD DESIRED TO RETAIN MACHTLEY'S PROVEN LEADERSHIP FOR A LONGER PERIOD OF TIME. FOLLOWING A MARKET ANALYSIS, THE BOARD'S COMPENSATION COMMITTEE ESTABLISHED A LONG-TERM DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN FOR MACHTLEY THAT LASTED APPROXIMATELY FIFTEEN ADDITIONAL YEARS. CONSISTENT WITH BRYANT'S LONG-TERM RETENTION STRATEGY, THE PLAN PROVIDED THAT MACHTLEY WOULD FORFEIT ALL PLAN PAYMENTS IF, BEFORE 2018, MACHTLEY VOLUNTARILY DECIDED TO LEAVE BRYANT OR WAS TERMINATED FOR CAUSE. IN DECEMBER 2017, MACHTLEY AND THE BOARD'S COMPENSATION COMMITTEE AGREED TO WAIVE THE PLAN'S FORFEITURE PROVISIONS WITH RESPECT TO APPROXIMATELY 96% OF PLAN BENEFITS. THIS ACTION CAUSED MACHTLEY TO RECOGNIZE SUCH AMOUNT AS TAXABLE INCOME FOR 2017. THE FORFEITURE PROVISIONS APPLICABLE TO THE REMAINING 4% OF TOTAL PLAN BENEFITS WERE NOT WAIVED IN CALENDAR 2017 AND WAS RECOGNIZED AS TAXABLE INCOME TOTALLING $223,198 IN 2018. FROM THIS AMOUNT, BRYANT WITHHELD FEDERAL AND STATE INCOME TAXES TOTALING $67,718. PART II, COLUMN C INCLUDES EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS TO SECTION 403(B) PLANS AND OTHER DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLANS. PART II, COLUMN D INCLUDES NON-TAXABLE BENEFITS INCLUDING UNDERGRADUATE TUITION REMISSION, EMPLOYER HEALTH BENEFITS, LIFE INSURANCE AND DISABILITY BENEFIT PREMIUM PAYMENTS, MOVING EXPENSES, AS WELL AS THE VALUE OF ON-CAMPUS HOUSING PROVIDED TO CERTAIN KEY EMPLOYEES UNDER THE REQUIREMENTS OF THEIR EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS.

-First-class travel - The College pays for the class above economy for all domestic and international travel for the president per employment contract. - Travel for Companions - The College pays for expenses for the President's spouse's travel as covered per contract with valid business reason. - Housing allowance or residence for personal use - The College provides housing to the president and a key employee as a condition of employment. The value of the employer provided housing has been determined to meet the criteria of Sec 119 and is therefore reported as a non-taxable benefit. - Health or social club dues - The College pays dues for the California Club for the sole purpose of conducting college business; no personal social activities are allowed. Because no personal social activities are conducted, the California Club dues are not included in taxable compensation.

-Robin Aspinall received post-employment severance payments subsequent to 6/30/2018. -Hiram Chodosh participates in a nonqualified deferred compensation plan under section 457(f). No distributions were made from the plan in 2018.

ExplntnTxt: The President is the only employee eligible for first class and spousal/companion travel. Other executives may be approved based on demonstrated medical need only. Rensselaer's President is allowed to use first class travel on Rensselaer business in accordance with the terms of her employment agreement, which was approved by independent members of the Compensation and Personnel Development Committee. The President's expenses are subject to review by the Board of Trustees, including any amounts for spousal or companion travel. The Board has oversight of strategic issues for facilities management, which include but are not limited to capital improvements and other costs for Rensselaer's president's residence. The Board of Rensselaer also oversees the review and audit of expenses of the President relating to the presidential residence and personal services associated with the upkeep of the residence. Such review occurs under the Board's oversight on an at least annual basis.

ExplntnTxt: Rensselaer maintains a performance incentive program in connection with the annual evaluation process for its President and Executive Officers. Eligibility for receipt of such incentive payments is limited to certain Executive Officers and held within the scope of reasonable compensation for like positions at peer institutions. Performance Awards are made following the evaluation process and subject to review by the Compensation and Personnel Development Committee of the Board based upon annual evaluations, with the amount of such awards, if any, at its discretion subject to applicable maximum limits by employment contract.

Part II - As noted in Column B(iii) and consistent with applicable federal guidance, executive positions with primary responsibility for endowment management and enrollment are not eligible for incentive compensation.

First class or charter travel: To facilitate its 24 hours security coverage for Dr. Robertson, Regent University provides charter air service for his business and personal flights. The University reports taxable income for Dr. Robertson's personal flights on his form 1099. It uses the Standard Industry Fair Level (SIFL) method as allowed under IRS rules for valuing personal flights. Dr. Robertson did not have an personal flights in FY 2020 and therefore did not receive a 1099 from Regent University. Travel for Companions: Regent University does not provide companion air travel for non-business purposes. Housing allowance: Regent University provides a ministerial housing allowance for qualified faculty and staff. This is reviewed and approved by the board.

Regent University regularly reviews the compensation of its officers and vice presidents to determine whether compensations is reasonable compared to similar positions of responsibility at other institutions. The Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees (in the absence of the Compensation Committee, the Audit Committee will assume this role) will periodically conduct an independent review of compensation which includes the President along with all officers and vice presidents. This process includes securing comparable compensation data from an independent source, reviewing the data to ensure that the compensation is reasonable and contemporaneous substantiation of the deliberation and decision making process takes place. Furthermore, when Regent University hires a new officer or vice president, it will ensure that all compensation is reasonable compared to similar positions of responsibility at other institutions.
The Vice President of Finance was released from his position in April 2019 and received a severance package for one year.
Any non-fixed payments were figured based on employees meeting performance goals.

The President's written contract includes housing as a condition of employment. Cleaning services to the President's house are provided as maintenance of a campus owned building, which is used for institutional events as well as being the personal residence of the President and family. No material services are performed in the private use portion of the residence, therefore, the value of the services is not included in taxable compensation. The President's written contract allows for first-class travel when travelling during off-peak hours or foregoing a one-night hotel stay. The value of first-class travel was not included in taxable compensation.

Former Assistant Vice President of Institutional Advancement, Megan Callaway, received a severance payment of $110,710 during 2019. The agreement is subject to a confidentiality clause; details will be provided to the IRS upon request. President Larissa Tiedens participated in a supplemental non-qualified retirement plan. A contribution of $84,000 was made during the 2018-2019 plan year.

Form 990, Schedule J, Part I Line 1 - The President of the College is provided a home in close proximity to the campus as a condition of his employment. The value of the residence provided to the President on campus has not been assigned a fair market value and is not included in Schedule J, Part II, Column (d). As required, the College provides cleaning and maintenance services for the employer provided housing. The college occasionally requires the travel, at various business functions, of the President's spouse (who is also a part-time employee of the College, but whose compensation did not exceed $10,000 and therefore is not required to be disclosed on Schedule L) and the VP for Advancement's spouse. Travel depends on the nature of the function and the duties of the spouses are determined in advance and approved. In such instances full substantiation of the expenses is also required. Finally, the College pays the social club membership dues of the President and the Vice President for Advancement so that they may host donors and other business guests of the College at activities designed to benefit the College. To the extent that these individuals incur any personal expenses related to their social club usage, they are required to reimburse the College. All business expenditures must be substantiated to be excluded from their wages.

Nydegger, Monsignor Robert J. Wister, and Monsignor Gerald J. Buonopane). The value of the housing and related benefits are included in nontaxable benefits in Schedule J, Part II. Lyons, M.B.A. Their attendance at these organizations were exclusively business related in order to assist University Advancement with donor cultivation and Fundraising efforts. Such fees totaled $15,476, $20,188, and $24,193, respectively. Where applicable, the personal component of travel is included in taxable income. The University paid $221,952 in 2019 to the former VP for Administration as severance. During 2019, the University made an end of term payment to an employee pursuant to contract. Due to non-disclosure provisions in the contract, the University is not disclosing the employee's name. However, such payment is properly disclosed on Form 990, Part VII and Schedule J as taxable wages. The compensation information reported on Form 990 is from calendar year 2019, as required. All amounts paid and disclosed were pursuant to employment agreements and done so prior to the COVID pandemic that currently affects our students, employees and society in general.

Schedule J, Part I, Line 4 Retirement Plan The President participates in a non-qualified compensation retirement plan. The plan was created during 2010 with the approval of the executive committee, an independent and disinterested party, in order to align the president's total compensation with comparable universities and to ensure the president's long-term employment with Clarkson University. The current year distribution from the plan was $200,000, plus accrued interest, for a total of $200,181. This distribution is included in the total reported on Part II, Column B(iii).

Performance Awards The Executive Committee may, at its discretion, award the President a performance award each year in connection with an evaluation of his performance. The evaluation is based on his accomplishments against goals and objectives during the year. The President may, at his discretion, award employees with a performance award. The Head Men's Hockey Coach and the Head Women's Hockey Coach were given this award based on an evaluation of their was given this award based on an evaluation of his performance. The evaluation is based upon their accomplishments against goals and objectives during the year. Retirement Incentive Program Ruth Baltus received $142,316 and Peter Turner received $166,101 during 2019 pursuant to a retirement incentive program. This was a one-time program initiated in June 2018 to encourage a large scale retirement of faculty and staff. Employees were offered a fixed percentage of their salary in a lump sum payment if they committed to retiring within a certain period of time. The compensation received by the Ruth Baltus and Peter Turner under this program is included in Part II, column B(iii).

PARTICIPANTS CONSTRUCTIVELY RECEIVE A DISTRIBUTION FROM THE PLAN NO LATER THAN MARCH 15TH OF THE CALENDAR YEAR FOLLOWING THE CALENDAR YEAR IN WHICH AN AMOUNT IS VESTED AND TAXABLE PURSUANT TO A VESTING SCHEDULE AS SPECIFIED IN THE PLAN DOCUMENT. THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDENCE SHALL BE AVAILABLE, AND SHALL BE USED, FOR COLLEGE-RELATED BUSINESS AND ENTERTAINMENT ON A REGULAR AND CONTINUING BASIS. THE COLLEGE PAYS FOR CLUB DUES FOR THE PRESIDENT SO THAT HE CAN INTERACT WITH DONORS OF THE COLLEGE. THESE BENEFITS ARE NONTAXABLE. THE PRESIDENT ALSO HAS AN ARRANGEMENT WITH THE COLLEGE WHEREBY HIS DEFERRED COMPENSATION IS TO BE RECEIVED NET OF TAXES WITH THE TAXES BEING PAID BY THE COLLEGE ON HIS BEHALF.

For the President: Social club dues, whose members are business leaders in the local community; housing residence provided for the convenience of the University; travel for companion of a family member for bona fide business purpose of the University. Payments grossed up for inclusion in wages are (1) Social club dues for the president; (2) Cell phone allowances for top financial officer and two of the highest compensated employees. The allowance is available to all qualified employees; (3) Identity theft coverage for the president and top financial officer.

Bonus pay was made to the president as approved by the Board of Trustees. Bonus pay was made to the senior vice president of finance and administration and provost and senior vice president for academic affairs.

FIRST CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL: THE UNIVERSITY TRAVEL POLICY REQUIRES AIR TRAVEL ACCOMMODATIONS FOR ALL EMPLOYEES TO BE AT THE LOWEST COACH CLASS FARE AVAILABLE THAT MEETS BUSINESS NEEDS. THE POLICY DOES ALLOW FOR BUSINESS CLASS AIRFARE ON INTERNATIONAL FLIGHTS, BUT FIRST CLASS OR CHARTER TRAVEL IS ONLY ALLOWED IN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES WITH APPROPRIATE REVIEW AND APPROVAL AND WHERE THERE IS A BONA FIDE BUSINESS PURPOSE TO JUSTIFY THE ADDITIONAL COST. DURING THE TAX YEAR THREE OFFICERS TRAVELED FIRST CLASS ON LIMITED OCCASION. THESE TRAVEL EXPENSES WERE INCURRED FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS PURPOSES AND THEREFORE WERE NOT TREATED AS COMPENSATION TO THE LISTED INDIVIDUALS. TRAVEL FOR COMPANIONS: COMPANION OR SPOUSAL TRAVEL IS PROVIDED ONLY IN LIMITED CIRCUMSTANCES WHERE THE TRAVEL SERVES AN ESSENTIAL BUSINESS PURPOSE OF THE UNIVERSITY. DURING THE TAX YEAR, ONE OFFICER TRAVELED WITH THEIR SPOUSE ON LIMITED OCCASION. IN THIS INSTANCE, THE SPOUSE IS ALSO AN EMPLOYEE OF THE UNIVERSITY. WHERE THE SPOUSAL TRAVEL WAS DEEMED TO HAVE AN ESSENTIAL BUSINESS PURPOSE, THE AMOUNT WAS NOT TREATED AS COMPENSATION TO THE LISTED INDIVIDUAL. TAX INDEMNIFICATION AND GROSS-UP PAYMENTS: THE UNIVERSITY WILL PROVIDE TAX GROSS-UP PAYMENTS IN CERTAIN CIRCUMSTANCES WITH THE APPROPRIATE LEVELS OF REVIEW AND APPROVAL. DURING THE TAX YEAR, ONE OFFICER AND ONE HIGHLY COMPENSATED EMPLOYEE EACH RECEIVED A GROSS-UP PAYMENT. THIS BENEFIT WAS TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE LISTED INDIVIDUALS. HOUSING ALLOWANCE OR RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE: THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES THE PRESIDENT WITH AN ON-CAMPUS RESIDENCE (THE "NICHOLS HOUSE") AND REQUIRES THE PRESIDENT TO USE THE HOUSE AS A PRIMARY RESIDENCE THROUGHOUT THE TERM OF OFFICE. THE PRESIDENT'S USE OF THE NICHOLS HOUSE IS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT AND FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY, THEREFORE IT IS EXEMPT FROM TAXATION UNDER INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 119. HEALTH OR SOCIAL CLUB DUES: UNIVERSITY POLICY ALLOWS FOR CORPORATE SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIPS, BUT SUCH MEMBERSHIPS ARE FOR STRICT BUSINESS USE. SUCH DEPARTMENTAL OR DIVISIONAL MEMBERSHIPS CANNOT BE USED FOR ANY PERSONAL USE. AS SUCH, USE OF SUCH MEMBERSHIPS FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS IS NOT TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. INDIVIDUAL SOCIAL CLUB MEMBERSHIPS PAID FOR BY THE UNIVERSITY, EVEN IF USED PRIMARILY FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS, ARE TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE LISTED INDIVIDUAL. PERSONAL SERVICES: THE UNIVERSITY EMPLOYS A HOUSEKEEPER TO CLEAN THE NICHOLS HOUSE AND ALSO PROVIDES THE PRESIDENT WITH A UNIVERSITY EMPLOYED DRIVER TO ACCOMMODATE HIS FREQUENT TRAVEL. THE PERSONAL AND BUSINESS TIME FOR BOTH THE HOUSEKEEPER AND THE DRIVER ARE LOGGED AND ANY PERSONAL USE IS TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE PRESIDENT.

WRITTEN POLICIES FOR PAYMENT OR REIMBURSEMENT OR PROVISION OF EXPENSES FOR ITEMS CHECKED IN 1A: IN GENERAL UNIVERSITY POLICY AND PROCEDURES OR CONTRACTUAL OBLIGATIONS ARE FOLLOWED IN PROVIDING THE ABOVE LISTED BENEFITS TO THE LISTED EMPLOYEES. THE UNIVERSITY DOES NOT HAVE A WRITTEN POLICY FOR GROSS-UP PAYMENTS. THE GROSS UP PAYMENT MADE IS IN CONNECTION WITH A CONTRACTUAL OBLIGATION. THERE ARE NO WRITTEN POLICIES FOR THE PROVISION OF THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSING AND RELATED PERSONAL SERVICES; HOWEVER, THE PROVISIONS ARE INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT WITH THE PRESIDENT. THE PRESIDENT'S RESIDENCE IS LOCATED ON CAMPUS AND IT IS INCLUDED IN HIS EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT THAT HE MUST LIVE THERE, SO IT IS EXEMPT FROM TAXATION UNDER INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 119 AND NOT INCLUDED IN THE W-2. THE UNIVERSITY HAS ESTABLISHED WRITTEN POLICIES AND PROCEDURES GOVERNING THE TRAVEL AND BUSINESS EXPENSES. THE POLICIES AND PROCEDURES INCLUDE REQUIREMENTS TO MEET THE IRS ACCOUNTABLE PLAN RULES. IT IS THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THE OFFICERS, DIRECTORS, TRUSTEES AND KEY EMPLOYEES TO COMPLY WITH THE WRITTEN POLICIES AND PROCEDURES AND TO EXERCISE GOOD JUDGEMENT IN DETERMINING THE BUSINESS PURPOSE. TRAVEL AND BUSINESS EXPENSES FOR OFFICERS AND DEANS ARE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY THE OFFICE OF THE PROVOST AND SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR ACADEMIC AFFAIRS OR THE OFFICE OF THE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION. THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE REVIEWS AND APPROVES TRAVEL AND BUSINESS EXPENSES OF THE SENIOR VICE PRESIDENTS AND THE CHAIR OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES REVIEWS AND APPROVES THE PRESIDENT'S TRAVEL AND BUSINESS EXPENSES.

THE SCHOOL OF MEDICINE OFFERS PERFORMANCE SUPPLEMENTS FOR CLINICAL FACULTY, DEPARTMENTAL CHAIRS, AND VICE DEANS. PERFORMANCE SUPPLEMENTS ARE RECOMMENDED BY THE DEAN OF THE SCHOOL OF MEDICINE. PERFORMANCE SUPPLEMENTS ARE INCENTIVE OPPORTUNITIES TIED TO PERFORMANCE OF DEPARTMENTAL, INSTITUTIONAL AND DISCRETIONARY GOALS INCLUDING RETENTION. PERFORMANCE INDICATORS MEASURE BUDGETARY (INCLUDING PROFITABILITY/EARNINGS), SAFETY, AND SERVICE EXCELLENCE PERFORMANCE. THE UNIVERSITY HAS IMPLEMENTED AN INCENTIVE PROGRAM FOR DEANS, KEY EMPLOYEES, AND PRINCIPAL ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICERS WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PRESIDENT. THE INCENTIVES RANGE FROM 4% TO 20% OF BASE SALARY. THE INCENTIVE PROGRAM WAS DEVELOPED AND APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD WITH INPUT TO THE PROGRAM'S STRUCTURE AND ADMINISTRATION PROVIDED TO THE COMMITTEE BY THE PRESIDENT, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION AND THE VICE PRESIDENT FOR HUMAN RESOURCES. IT IS ADMINISTERED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD. ANNUALLY, THE INCENTIVE AWARDS ARE RECOMMENDED BY THE PRESIDENT AND APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE APPROVED A ONE-TIME PROJECT COMPLETION BONUS FOR THE VICE PRESIDENT FOR DEVELOPMENT & ALMUNI RELATIONS AND THE VICE PRESIDENT FOR FACILITIES AND REAL ESTATE. IN ADDITION, THE VICE PRESIDENT OF INVESTMENTS AND CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER IS ELIGIBLE FOR PERFORMANCE SUPPLEMENTS. THESE SUPPLEMENTS ARE INCENTIVE OPPORTUNITIES DETERMINED USING BOTH QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE PERFORMANCE COMPONENTS. THESE SUPPLEMENTS ARE RECOMMENDED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES INVESTMENT COMMITTEE AND APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE APPROVED PAYMENT OF PERFORMANCE SUPPLEMENTS TO THE VICE PRESIDENT OF INVESTMENTS AND CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER IN DECEMBER 2019. THE JOHNS HOPKINS APPLIED PHYSICS LABORATORY (JHU/APL) IMPLEMENTED AN INCENTIVE COMPENSATION PROGRAM FOR THE JHU/APL DIRECTOR. THE PROGRAM DESIGN AND STRUCTURE WERE APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE JHU/APL BOARD OF MANAGERS (BOM). THE ANNUAL INCENTIVE FOR THE JHU/APL DIRECTOR RANGES FROM 0% TO 20% OF BASE PAY. OVERSIGHT OF THIS PROGRAM IS PROVIDED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOM WITH SUPPORT PROVIDED BY THE JHU/APL DIRECTOR OF TALENT SERVICES. THE SIZE OF THE ANNUAL INCENTIVES AWARDED TO THE JHU/APL DIRECTOR IS BASED UPON HIM MEETING SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES APPROVED AT THE BEGINNING OF THE CALENDAR YEAR BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOM. IN NOVEMBER OF EACH YEAR, THE BOM COMPENSATION COMMITTEE REVIEWS THE PROGRESS TOWARDS THE GOALS ACHIEVED BY THE JHU/APL DIRECTOR AND DETERMINES AND APPROVES THE PERCENTAGE OF THE INCENTIVE EARNED BY THE JHU/APL DIRECTOR.

COMPENSATION LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH'S EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION PROCESS INCLUDES THE FOLLOWING REVIEW AND ACTION BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES WHICH IS COMPRISED OF INDEPENDENT TRUSTEES. AN EVALUATION OF PERFORMANCE AGAINST GOALS IS CONDUCTED AT THE CLOSE OF A FISCAL YEAR TO DETERMINE THE LEVEL OF ORGANIZATIONAL AND INDIVIDUAL PERFORMANCE OF THE CEO AND SENIOR EXECUTIVES AS TO DETERMINE MERIT AND INCENTIVE PAY ACTIONS. MARKET DATA FOR BASE SALARY, TOTAL CASH COMPENSATION AND TOTAL COMPENSATION IS PROVIDED BY AN INDEPENDENT THIRD PARTY TO THE COMMITTEE AND REFLECTS A MARKET BASKET OF SIMILARLY SIZED ORGANIZATIONS WITH COMPARABLE EXECUTIVE POSITIONS. UPON REVIEW AND DISCUSSION OF THE RELATED DATA AND INFORMATION THE COMMITTEE TAKES ACTION WHICH IS RECORDED IN THE MEETING MINUTES WHICH ARE THEN FILED FOR FUTURE REFERENCE. ---------------------------

NO DISTRIBUTION THE UNIVERSITY OF PENNSYLVANIA HEALTH SYSTEM (THE "HEALTH SYSTEM") MAINTAINS A SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN ("SERP") DESIGNED FOR SENIOR ADMINISTRATORS OF THE HEALTH SYSTEM, AS DESIGNATED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES, WHO ARE ACTIVELY EMPLOYED BY THE HEALTH SYSTEM WHEN THE CONTRIBUTIONS ARE MADE. VESTING IN THE SERP OCCURS AFTER EACH THREE YEARS OF PARTICIPATION AND UPON THE OCCURRENCE OF CERTAIN EVENTS (ATTAINMENT OF AGE 65, DEATH, DISABILITY, OR INVOLUNTARY TERMINATION WITHOUT "CAUSE"). CONTRIBUTIONS FOR THOSE WHO HAVE REACHED AGE 65 WILL BE FULLY VESTED WHEN MADE. UPON REACHING A VESTING DATE, PARTICIPANTS WILL AUTOMATICALLY RECEIVE A FULL DISTRIBUTION WHICH IS TAXABLE AS EARNED INCOME. PARTICIPANTS WHO VOLUNTARILY TERMINATE BEFORE VESTING WILL FORFEIT THE BALANCE IN THEIR ACCOUNTS. NON FIXED PAYMENTS THE PURPOSE OF THE LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH (LG) ANNUAL INCENTIVE PLAN (THE PLAN) IS TO REINFORCE STRATEGIC PERFORMANCE PRIORITIES FOR SENIOR MANAGEMENT AND MANAGEMENT EMPLOYEES AND TO ENCOURAGE THE HIGHEST LEVEL OF PERFORMANCE IN THE DELIVERY OF HEALTHCARE SERVICES. AS A REWARD FOR EMPLOYEES' CONTRIBUTIONS TO LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH'S SUCCESS, THE PLAN PROVIDES THE OPPORTUNITY TO EARN MEANINGFUL INCENTIVE COMPENSATION BASED ON THE PERFORMANCE OF LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH AND THE INDIVIDUAL PARTICIPANTS. SPECIFICALLY, THE PLAN IS DESIGNED TO: *FOCUS PARTICPANTS ON THE ACHIEVEMENT OF ORGANIZATION GOALS RELATED TO PEOPLE, SERVICE, QUALITY/SAFETY, FINANCIAL AND GROWTH; *PROMOTE AND FOSTER A TEAM ORIENTED CULTURE; *STRENGTHEN LANCASTER GENERAL HEALTH'S ABILITY TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN SUPERIOR TALENT, RECOGNIZE AND REWARD ACCOMPLISHMENTS THAT CLEARLY ADVANCE THE ORGANIZATION'S MISSION, AND DRIVE STRATEGIES; *PROVIDE INCENTIVE AWARDS THAT CAN BE ADJUSTED ANNUALLY FOR DIFFERENT BUSINESS CONDITIONS AND BUSINESS PLAN PRIORITIES WITHOUT CHANGING BASIC DESIGN FEATURES OF THE PLAN; AND *PROVIDE ANNUAL INCENTIVE OPPORTUNITIES WITH DUE CONSIDERATION TO THE REQUIREMENTS OF THE INTERMEDIATE SANCTIONS LAW AND THE REGULATIONS THERE UNDER. ---------------------------

HEALTH AND SOCIAL CLUB DUES: THE UNIVERSITY PAYS MEMBERSHIP DUES AT THE HARTFORD GOLF CLUB FOR THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY. As a condition of employment the President is required to live in housing supplied by the College. In addition, travel for her companion is provided when they are representing the Institution at public functions across the country. All travel expenses do require documentation and are not taxable to the individual. All of the Vice Presidents have small discretionary funds with their individual departments. All expenses do require documentation and are not taxable to the individuals.

-First-class travel - The College pays for the class above economy for all domestic and international travel for the president per employment contract. - Travel for Companions - The College pays for expenses for the President's spouse's travel as covered per contract with valid business reason. - Housing allowance or residence for personal use - The College provides housing to the president and a key employee as a condition of employment. The value of the employer provided housing has been determined to meet the criteria of Sec 119 and is therefore reported as a non-taxable benefit. - Health or social club dues - The College pays dues for the California Club for the sole purpose of conducting college business; no personal social activities are allowed. Because no personal social activities are conducted, the California Club dues are not included in taxable compensation.

-The severance payment agreements are confidential, detail is available upon request. -Hiram Chodosh participates in a nonqualified deferred compensation plan under section 457(f). No distributions were made from the plan in 2019.
The organization provided one-time performance related bonuses.

IRS instructions to Form 990 require that the fair market value of housing provided to employees by their employers be reported on Form 990, Part VII, Section A and Schedule J, Part II. As a condition of employment, the President of the University is required to reside on campus premises. The residence serves both as a personal residence as well as a venue for carrying out University business. The University has determined that the value of the use of the personal residence is not considered taxable income to the President as provided in Internal Revenue Code Section 119. For tax year 2018, the President's use of the residence is conservatively estimated at $42,000. This estimated value is based on a fair rental value of $3,500 per month for similar houses in the area. This value includes maintenance of the property, landscaping, and snow removal.

Housing was provided for the President. Only a portion of the housing is considered taxable since a substantial portion of the residence is used for College events and activities. Transportation is provided for the President's spouse when their spouse is considered to be traveling on College business.
President Williams left the College as of June 17, 2019. President Williams received payments totaling $455,731 during the fiscal year ending June 30,2020.

THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY RECEIVES A HOUSING ALLOWANCE WHICH IS INCLUDED IN HIS/HER TAXABLE INCOME. THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE CAN TRAVEL WITH THE PRESIDENT AND IS CONSIDERED A REPRESENTATIVE OF THE UNIVERSITY. ALSO, THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES CLUB MEMBERSHIPS TO CERTAIN KEY INDIVIDUALS FOR RELATIONSHIP BUILDING PURPOSES. DUE TO THE NATURE OF THESE MEMBERSHIPS, THE COSTS ARE INCLUDED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S COMPENSATION.

OCCASIONALLY THE PRESIDENT'S HUSBAND WILL ACCOMPANY THE PRESIDENT ON COLLEGE FUNDRAISING EVENTS. THE COLLEGE PROVIDES FUNDING FOR HIS TRAVEL COSTS. THESE TRAVEL COSTS ARE NOT CONSIDERED COMPENSATION AS HE IS PARTICIPATING IN FUNDRAISING FOR THE COLLEGE. REIMBURSEMENTS FOR TRAVEL COST MUST FOLLOW THE COLLEGE'S PURCHASING AND ACCOUNTS PAYABLE POLICIES. THESE POLICIES INCLUDE REQUIREMENTS FOR DOCUMENTATION AND RECEIPTS. THE PRESIDENT IS PROVIDED HOUSING BY THE COLLEGE. THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE IS CONSIDERED A PART OF THE COLLEGE'S CAMPUS AND IS USED FOR COLLEGE EVENTS AND ENTERTAINING. THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSING IS CONSIDERED NONTAXABLE AS IT IS PROVIDED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE COLLEGE.

COMPENSATION IS REVIEWED ANNUALLY. THIS REVIEW INCLUDES COST OF LIVING STATISTICS, COMPENSATION PAID FOR SIMILAR POSITIONS AT OTHER SIMILAR COLLEGES, AND COMPENSATION PAID LOCALLY FOR LIKE POSITIONS. A STANDARD ACHIEVEMENT INCREASE IS DETERMINED AND IS APPROVED BY THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES DURING THE JUNE MEETING IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE APPROVAL OF THE FOLLOWING YEAR'S BUDGET. ALL STAFF INCREASES ARE REVIEWED BY THE PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENTS, AND HEADS OF DEPARTMENTS. THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES FOLLOWS THE PRINCIPAL AND POLICIES OUTLINED IN KNOX'S EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION PROGRAM AS APPROVED MAY 2, 2016. COMPENSATION FOR EXECUTIVES OF THE COLLEGE IS DETERMINED BY EVALUATION OF A VARIETY OF FACTORS, INCLUDING THE SKILLS, TENURE, EXPERIENCE AND PERFORMANCE OF THE EXECUTIVE; THE DIFFICULTY OF REPLACING THE EXECUTIVE AND THE IMPORTANCE OF THE POSITION TO THE COLLEGE; AND HISTORICAL COMPENSATION LEVELS AND INTERNAL PAY EQUITY ISSUES. ALL COMPENSATION AND OTHER FINANCIAL BENEFITS FOR COLLEGE EMPLOYEES WHO ARE DISQUALIFIED PERSONS ARE TO BE APPROVED IN ADVANCE OF PAYMENT OR AGREEMENT FOR PAYMENT BY THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES.

METHODS USED TO ESTABLISH COMPENSATION: DURING THE 2018-2019 FISCAL YEAR, THE COMPENSATION OF ALL OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY WAS REVIEWED. THE SALARY DATA WAS BENCHMARKED USING CUPA SALARY FOR ADMINISTRATORS IN HIGHER EDUCATION AND WAS SET WITHIN THE CONSTRAINTS OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEE'S APPROVED OPERATING BUDGET.

The College has a nonqualified 457(b) deferred compensation plan for its President. Contributions to the plan are invested in equity securities. The college made contributions of $19,000 for calendar year 2019. At May 31, 2020, $301,815 was accrued as a liability and set aside in a separate account for this benefit. The assets held in this account are the property of the College and are subject to the claims of the general creditors. The College accounts for the assets held by this plan as investments held for deferred compensation recorded in other assets, with the related liability recorded in other liabilities on the statements of financial position.

The target opportunity for the discretionary award is established through market compensation and internal policy so as to relate pay, performance and rewards. Upon reviewing annual performance, the Executive Committee of the Board of Trustees determines results and the granting of discretionary awards, if any.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Schedule J, Part I, Line 4b Supplemental nonqualified retirement plan
ExplntnTxt: THE MIDWESTERN UNIVERSITY SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLAN II (THE "PLAN"), EFFECTIVE JUNE 30, 2017, HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED FOR THE BENEFIT OF DR. KATHLEEN GOEPPINGER, THE PRESIDENT AND CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER ("CEO") OF THE UNIVERSITY. THE PLAN IS INTENDED TO PROVIDE THE CEO WITH A TARGET RETIREMENT BENEFIT FOR HER SERVICE WITH MWU FOR THE PERIOD BEGINNING ON HER 65TH BIRTHDAY AND ENDING ON HER 75TH BIRTHDAY BASED UPON HER AVERAGE COMPENSATION FOR THE THREE CONSECUTIVE CALENDAR YEARS OF THIS PERIOD DURING WHICH HER COMPENSATION IS THE HIGHEST, WITH A LEVEL OF ANNUAL ACCRUALS APPROXIMATING 82.5% OF MARKET, AND OFFSETS BY OTHER RETIREMENT PLANS. THE BENEFIT VESTS AND WILL BE PAID IN TWO INSTALLMENTS FOLLOWING THE CEO'S 70TH AND 75TH BIRTHDAYS RESPECTIVELY, EACH DETERMINED WITH APPROPRIATE PROJECTIONS, CALCULATIONS AND RE-CALCULATIONS AS REQUIRED. THE CONSULTING FIRM OF KORN FERRY HAY GROUP WAS RETAINED TO CONSTRUCT A PROPOSAL TO ESTABLISH THE PLAN AND TO REVIEW THE PRESIDENT AND CEO 'S TOTAL COMPENSATION, THE RESULTS OF WHICH WERE REVIEWED AND APPROVED BY BOTH THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES AND THE FULL BOARD OF TRUSTEES. DURING CALENDAR YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2019, $167,200 WAS ACCRUED BY UNIVERSITY FOR THE PROVISION OF RETIREMENT BENEFITS UNDER THE PLAN. THIS AMOUNT IS INCLUDED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN C. THIS REPRESENTS ONE FIFTH OF THE AMOUNT THAT WILL BE PAID AFTER HER 75TH BIRTHDAY. IN FEBRUARY OF 2018, THE FIRST INSTALLMENT PAYABLE UNDER THE PLAN OF $836,000 WAS PAID TO DR. GOEPPINGER.

BENEFITS PROVIDED WELLESLEY COLLEGE'S POLICY IS THAT THE COLLEGE WILL NOT PAY FOR - OR REIMBURSE - TRAVEL, MEALS, AND EXPENSES OF THE SPOUSE/PARTNER OF AN EMPLOYEE WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PRESIDENT. SPECIFICALLY, WHILE PERFORMING HER OFFICIAL DUTIES IN THE AREA OF DEVELOPMENT, ALUMNAE RELATIONS, AND OTHER BUSINESS OF THE COLLEGE, THE PRESIDENT MAY BE ACCOMPANIED BY HER SPOUSE, WHO IS EXPECTED TO MAKE AN IMPORTANT CONTRIBUTION TO ACHIEVING THE PURPOSES OF THE TRAVEL OR EVENTS. IN THOSE CASES, THE COLLEGE'S POLICY IS TO AUTHORIZE THE PAYMENT OF ALL TRAVEL AND RELATED EXPENSES OF THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE. THE COLLEGE PROVIDES HOUSING TO CERTAIN EMPLOYEES AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT FOR THE CONVENIENCE AND BENEFIT OF THE COLLEGE. THE PRESIDENT, PROVOST AND DEAN OF COLLEGE, AND DEAN OF STUDENTS EACH RECEIVED A HOUSING ALLOWANCE. THESE HOUSING ALLOWANCE AMOUNTS WERE NOT TAXABLE AND WERE NOT INCLUDED IN THEIR W-2. THE HOUSING REQUIREMENT AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT IS DOCUMENTED IN THE EMPLOYEE'S FILES. THE COLLEGE WILL NOT PAY FOR PERSONAL SERVICES WITH THE EXCEPTION OF THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE. BECAUSE THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE IS USED EXTENSIVELY FOR COLLEGE BUSINESS, HOUSEKEEPING SERVICES ARE PROVIDED FOR THE GENERAL SPACE. A CHEF WILL BE AT THE PRESIDENT'S HOUSE TO PROVIDE MEALS FOR BUSINESS PURPOSE FUNCTIONS. PERSONAL SERVICES PROVIDED TO EMPLOYEES ARE APPROPRIATELY REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION.

HAWKINS, AS PRESIDENT OF UNION, HAS AGREED AND IS OBLIGED AS A CONDITION OF HER EMPLOYMENT, AND AS A BENEFIT TO UNION, TO RESIDE DURING THE TERM OF THIS AGREEMENT AT BALDWIN PLACE ON THE CAMPUS OF UNION COLLEGE. UNION SHALL PAY ALL UTILITIES, TAXES, INSURANCE AND EXPENSE OF MAINTENANCE AND UPKEEP FOR BALDWIN PLACE, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO REPAIRING AND REMODELING BALDWIN PLACE IN ORDER TO KEEP IT AS A RESIDENCE BEFITTING A COLLEGE PRESIDENT. RESIDENCE FOR PERSONAL USE THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY PERIODICALLY STAYS OVERNIGHT IN UNIVERSITY OWNED FACILITIES. THE FAIR MARKET RENT VALUE OF THESE LODGING ACCOMMODATIONS ARE REPORTED ANNUALLY IN THE PRESIDENT'S FORM W-2 ANNUAL WAGE AND TAX STATEMENT AS A TAXABLE FRINGE BENEFIT, AND HAVE BEEN INCLUDED IN COLUMN B (III) OF SCHEDULE J AS OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION. SOCIAL CLUB DUES THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES FOR THE ANNUAL COST OF MEMBERSHIP DUES IN TWO SOCIAL CLUBS FOR ITS PRESIDENT, LOCAL TO CAMPUS. THE FULL AMOUNT OF DUES PAID IS REPORTED ANNUALLY ON THE PRESIDENT'S FORM W-2 ANNUAL WAGE AND TAX STATEMENT AS A TAXABLE FRINGE BENEFIT PURSUANT TO INTERNAL REVENUE CODE SECTION 274(A)(3), AND HAS BEEN DISCLOSED IN COLUMN B (III) OF SCHEDULE J. THE USE OF THE CLUBS IS PRIMARILY FOR THE PURPOSES OF BUSINESS MEETINGS AND COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT FURTHERING THE INTERESTS OF THE UNIVERSITY. USE OF THE CLUBS IS DOCUMENTED AND ANY COSTS FOR PERSONAL MEALS OR USE ARE PAID BY THE PRESIDENT PERSONALLY WHEN INCURRED.
ONE FORMER OFFICER RECEIVED SEVERANCE COMPENSATION IN THE AMOUNT OF $585,417. THE AMOUNT WAS REPORTED IN FORM 990 PART VII, LINE 1A AND SCHEDULE J, PART II AS REQUIRED.

DURING THE YEAR, THE UNIVERSITY'S PRESIDENT AND EXECUTIVE VICE PRESIDENT PARTICIPATED IN A SUPPLEMENTAL NON-QUALIFIED RETIREMENT PLAN. NO AMOUNTS WERE PAID DURING THE YEAR, AND AMOUNTS ACCRUED ARE SUBJECT TO A SUBSTANTIAL RISK OF FORFEITURE.

SEVERAL OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES RECEIVED NON-FIXED, NON-CONTRACTUAL PAYMENTS REPRESENTING PERFORMANCE PAYMENTS DETERMINED ON A DISCRETIONARY BASIS RESULTING FROM ANNUAL PERFORMANCE APPRAISAL AND COMPENSATION REVIEW.

THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNIVERSITY IS CONTRACTUALLY OBLIGATED TO LIVE IN HOUSING ADJACENT TO THE UNIVERSITY. SUCH HOUSING IS FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY; ACCORDINGLY THERE ARE MULTIPLE FUNCTIONS HELD AT THE PRESIDENT'S HOME ANNUALLY. HOUSING VALUE IS APPROXIMATELY $20,000 ANNUALLY AND IS NOT TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE PRESIDENT.

FOR FLIGHTS THAT EXCEED TWO HOURS IN DURATION, THE PRESIDENT IS APPROVED TO TRAVEL IN BUSINESS CLASS (OR IF NOT AVAILABLE, THEN THE NEXT HIGHER CLASS OF TRAVEL ABOVE COACH). THESE EXPENSES ARE NOT INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE FRINGE BENEFITS. THE PRESIDENT'S SPOUSE IS EXPECTED TO ACCOMPANY THE PRESIDENT ON UNIVERSITY BUSINESS TRAVEL WHERE APPROPRIATE AND THE RELATED TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE NOT A TAXABLE FRINGE BENEFIT. THE UNIVERSITY REQUIRES THE PRESIDENT TO LIVE IN A UNIVERSITY OWNED RESIDENCE. PERSONAL SERVICES PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT ARE LIMITED TO CUSTODIAL CLEANING OF THE RESIDENCE. THE PRESIDENT ALSO RECEIVES TAX GROSS-UP PAYMENTS RELATING TO THE PERSONAL USE BENEFIT OF THE RESIDENCE. THE PERSONAL USE VALUE OF THE RESIDENCE IS REPORTED AS A PORTION OF "OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION" ON SCHEDULE J, PART II. THE UNIVERSITY PAID COUNTRY CLUB DUES ON BEHALF OF RALPH KUNCL, PRESIDENT, CORY NOMURA, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT FOR FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION, AND KEVIN DYERLY, VP ENROLLMENT. THE PERSONAL USE PORTION OF THE VALUE OF THE COUNTRY CLUB DUES IS INCLUDED IN REPORTABLE (TAXABLE) COMPENSATION FOR THESE EMPLOYEES ON FORM 990.

LINE 4B - RALPH KUNCL, PRESIDENT, AND CORY NOMURA, SENIOR VP FINANCE AND ADMINISTRATION, PARTICIPATE IN A NONQUALIFIED DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN UNDER SECTION 457(F). RALPH KUNCL'S FY 2019-2020 DEFERRED COMPENSATION WILL BE VESTED AS OF JUNE 30, 2027. CORY NOMURA'S FY 2019-2020 DEFERRED COMPENSATION WILL BE FORFEITED DUE TO HIS DEPARTURE FROM THE UNIVERSITY EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2020. DEFERRED COMPENSATION IS SUBJECT TO CONTINUAL EMPLOYMENT THROUGH THE VESTING PERIOD EXCEPT FOR IN THE EVENT OF DEATH OR FULL PERMANENT DISABILITY. CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE 457(F) PLAN FOR KUNCL AND NOMURA IN THE CURRENT YEAR WERE $110,000 AND $50,000, RESPECTIVELY, AND ARE INCLUDED IN "RETIREMENT AND OTHER DEFERRED COMPENSATION" ON SCHEDULE J, PART II.

ExplntnTxt: ELIGIBLE EXECUTIVES PARTICIPATE IN A PROGRAM THAT PROVIDES FOR SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT BENEFITS. ANY AMOUNT ULTIMATELY PAID UNDER THE PROGRAM TO THE EXECUTIVE IS REPORTED AS COMPENSATION ON FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN B IN THE YEAR PAID. FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SCHEDULE J, PART I, LINE 1A AND 1B
ExplntnTxt: THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT PROVIDES AS A CONDITION OF HIS EMPLOYMENT AS PRESIDENT, THAT HE RESIDE IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO ITS NYC CAMPUS FOR THE BENEFITS AND CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY IN HAVING THE FUNCTIONS OF THE OFFICE OF THE PRESIDENT EFFICIENTLY DISCHARGED. THE PRESIDENT'S CONTRACT FURTHER REQUIRES FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE UNIVERSITY THAT HIS RESIDENCE BE AVAILABLE AND SHALL BE USED, FOR THE UNIVERSITY-RELATED BUSINESS AND ENTERTAINMENT ON A REGULAR AND CONTINUING BASIS. IN ADDITION, THE PRESIDENT'S CONTRACT PROVIDES THAT THE UNIVERSITY SHALL PAY FOR ALL MAINTENANCE AND OPERATING EXPENSES, INCLUDING GENERAL MAINTENANCE, HOUSEKEEPING, AND ALL UTILITIES INCLUDING TELEPHONE, CABLE, INTERNET, ELECTRIC, GAS, AND WATER. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PRESIDENT'S CONTRACT, THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PAYS FOR THE PRESIDENT'S USE OF A RECENT MODEL AUTOMOBILE AND A FULL TIME DRIVER TO ASSIST HIM IN IMPLEMENTING HIS DUTIES ON BEHALF OF THE UNIVERSITY, AS WELL AS ANNUAL DUES AND MEMBERSHIP FEES FOR SOCIAL CLUBS TO FACILITATE THE PRESIDENT'S FUNDRAISING, DEVELOPMENT AND RECRUITING EFFORTS ON BEHALF OF THE UNIVERSITY. THESE COSTS ARE TREATED AS NONTAXABLE BENEFITS TO THE PRESIDENT. SHORT TERM HOUSING ALLOWANCES ARE OCCASIONALLY PROVIDED PER INITIAL HIRING AGREEMENTS AND ARE TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION. CHAUFFEUR SERVICES ARE PROVIDED PER EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS FOR UNIVERSITY BUSINESS; ANY PERSONAL TRAVEL EXPENSES ARE TREATED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE RESPECTIVE OFFICER. SOCIAL CLUB DUES ARE PAID IN ACCORDANCE WITH INDIVIDUAL EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS OR BUSINESS CONSIDERATIONS.

THE COLLEGE PROVIDES A RESIDENCE AND HOUSEHOLD SERVICES FOR THE PRESIDENT, JAMES REYNOLDS. THE RESIDENCE IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE INCOME. THE RESIDENCE IS FURNISHED FOR THE CONVENIENCE OF THE COLLEGE, AND IT IS AVAILABLE FOR USE TO HOST FACULTY, STAFF, AND STUDENT FUNCTIONS. THE PRESIDENT WAS REQUIRED TO LIVE IN THE RESIDENCE AS A CONDITION OF EMPLOYMENT, AND THE RESIDENCE IS CONTIGUOUS TO THE COLLEGE'S CAMPUS.
The President is provided a house on campus in recognition of the President's residence being required and used for the University business. This is not included in taxable income.

PARK UNIVERSITY PROVIDED ON CAMPUS HOUSING TO THE PRESIDENT. THE FAIR MARKET VALUE QUALIFIED AS NONTAXABLE UNDER CODE SECTION 119 AND IS NOT INCLUDED ON FORM W-2. THE PRESIDENT WAS PROVIDED PERSONAL SERVICES IN THE FORM OF HOUSEKEEPING OF THE PRESIDENT'S ON CAMPUS RESIDENCE. THE RESIDENCE WAS USED AS A LESS FORMAL MEETING VENUE FOR THE PRESIDENT TO INTERACT WITH DONORS, TRUSTEES, VISITING DIGNITARIES, PROFESSORS, ETC. THE FAIR MARKET VALUE WAS NOT TAXABLE INCOME BECAUSE COSTS OF HOUSEKEEPING ASSOCIATED WITH SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC USE OF THE RESIDENCE WAS CONSIDERED AN APPROPRIATE BUSINESS EXPENSE.

BY THE NATURE OF THE POSITION, THE CEO IS REQUIRED TO FULFILL SEVERAL OBLIGATIONS/COMMITMENTS WHICH MAY RESULT IN TRAVELLING FIRST-CLASS AND/OR CHARTER TO ACCOMMODATE REQUIRED APPOINTMENTS. FURTHER, HIS SPOUSE MAY ACCOMPANY HIM AS DICTATED BY HER REQUIRED PRESENCE FOR AN EVENT. THE CEO HAS AVAILABLE TO HIM A DISCRETIONARY FUND (BUDGETED EACH YEAR) FOR ASSISTING INDIVIDUALS AND/OR PROJECTS IN NEED OF SUPPORT. FURTHER, THE CEO IS REQUIRED TO RESIDE IN COLLEGE-OWNED HOUSING FOR THE PURPOSE OF BEING A PRESENCE ON CAMPUS AND FOR ENTERTAINMENT PURPOSES. AS THE RESULT OF LIVING IN A COLLEGE-OWNED RESIDENCE, THE COLLEGE PROVIDES, AS WITH ALL CAMPUS BUILDINGS, LIGHT HOUSEKEEPING. THE POSITION OF CEO ALSO REQUIRES MEMBERSHIP IN CERTAIN SOCIAL/ACADEMIC ORGANIZATIONS AND THEREFORE THE COLLEGE PROVIDES THE DUES/FEES ASSOCIATED WITH THAT MEMBERSHIP. FROM TIME TO TIME THE COLLEGE UTILIZES THE COLLEGE PRESIDENT'S PERSONAL RESIDENCE FOR COLLEGE EVENTS AND HOUSING OF COLLEGE GUESTS.

THE PRUDENTIAL COMMITTEE (EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE) OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES APPROVES THE CEO'S ANNUAL SALARY. THE TREASURER'S OFFICE SECURES SALARY INFORMATION SUPPLIED BY THE CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION, IRS FORM 990 OF OTHER ORGANIZATIONS, COMPENSATION CONSULTANTS, AND WRITTEN CONTRACT. THIS INFORMATION IS THEN PROVIDED TO THE PRUDENTIAL COMMITTEE FOR THEIR REVIEW AND EVALUATION.
DEPENDING ON THE LEVELS OF GIFT REVENUE, BONUSES WERE PAID.

THE PRESIDENT'S EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT HAS PROVISIONS FOR A NON-ACCOUNTABLE EXPENSE ACCOUNT AND HOUSING ALLOWANCE. FOR THE CALENDAR YEAR 2019, THE PRESIDENT UTILIZED EMPLOYER PROVIDED HOUSING INSTEAD OF A HOUSING ALLOWANCE. THIS NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IS REPORTED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN D.

THE UNIVERSITY HAS A COMPENSATION COMMITTEE THAT ESTABLISHES THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION. FOR THE CURRENT FISCAL YEAR, THE COMMITTEE ENGAGED SERVICES FROM AN INDEPENDENT CONSULTANT TO ASSIST WITH THE DETERMINATION OF COMPENSATION. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE, HOWEVER, INDEPENDENTLY APPROVED AND AWARDED THE FINAL COMPENSATION PACKAGE.

PURSUANT TO A WRITTEN EMPLOYMENT CONTRACT, THE PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENTS, GENERAL COUNSEL, AND CHIEF INFORMATION OFFICER OF THE UNIVERSITY PARTICIPATE IN AN ANNUAL VARIABLE COMPENSATION PROGRAM. PAYMENTS ARE CONTINGENT ON THE ACHIEVEMENT OF ATTAINABLE BUSINESS PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES ESTABLISHED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. THE MAXIMUM POTENTIAL AMOUNT OF DEFERRED COMPENSATION FOR INDIVIDUALS EMPLOYED DURING THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2020 WAS ACCRUED AT YEAR END AND IS REPORTED ON THE 2019 FORM 990, SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN C. THE BONUS PAYMENT IS DISCLOSED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN (B)(II) AT THE ACTUAL AMOUNT OF THE PAYOUT, WITH AMOUNTS ACCRUED IN THE FISCAL YEAR ENDED JUNE 30, 2019 DISCLOSED ON SCHEDULE J, PART II, COLUMN F.

The spouse of the President sometimes accompanies him to conferences and meetings during the year. The College pays for her travel expenses. Also, the President receives an annual housing allowance for $25,000 as well as drives a College vehicle for business and personal use. The annual lease values and the housing allowances are added to his taxable compensation.
THE PRESIDENT RECEIVES A HOUSING ALLOWANCE AS AN ORDAINED MINISTER.

THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES COMPLETED A PERFORMANCE EVALUATION OF THE PRESIDENT AND APPROVED HIS COMPENSATION. THE COMMITTEE USED PEER SALARY DATA AND PUBLISHED SURVEYS FOR COMPARISONS. THE COMMITTEE ALSO REVIEWED THE COMPENSATION OF KEY EMPLOYEES.

Some persons listed on Schedule J, Part II are awarded bonus payments based on their accomplishment of certain metrics. From time-to-time, one-time performance bonuses are awarded to officers and employees for extraordinary performances. Bonuses are recommended by a member of management and are awarded only after approval from the division president, CFO, and CEO. All incentive compensation is considered as part of total reasonable compensation.

The President's spouse accompanies her on business related travel when his presence is expected and necessary for the event. Travel expenses for spousal or companion travel are not reimbursed under the current University policy, except in very limited cases where the president's spouse is required or is expected to attend the function. The President is provided a residence on campus. Along with providing housing for the President and her spouse, the residence is also used for various university events and functions hosted by the President. Staff employed by the University provides housekeeping services at the President's residence. Catering services are also provided for university functions and events held at the President's residence for University purpose.

THE OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES OF THE YWCA-NCA PERFORM SERVICES FOR HCCE. YWCA-NCA IS REIMBURSED BY HCCE FOR AN ALLOCATED PORTION OF THE COMPENSATION OF EACH OFFICER AND KEY EMPLOYEE. THE COMPENSATION POLICIES AND PROCEDURES ARE MONITORED BY YWCA-NCA. COMPENSATION OF OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES OF YWCA-NCA IS DETERMINED BASED ON SEVERAL FACTORS INCLUDING MARKET DATA, COMPARABLE DATA FROM THE NONPROFIT SECTOR FOR SIMILAR POSITIONS, AND ACTUAL HISTORICAL COMPENSATION OF INDIVIDUALS SEEKING EMPLOYMENT FOR VACANT POSITIONS.

THE FOLLOWING INDIVIDUAL RECEIVED SEVERANCE PAYMENTS IN 2019: PAUL ARRINGTON - $175,729 ENTITIES WITHIN THE PROVIDENCE SYSTEM SPONSOR NON-QUALIFIED SUPPLEMENTAL EXECUTIVE RETIREMENT PLANS FOR CERTAIN EXECUTIVES. THE PLANS PROVIDE FOR EMPLOYER CONTRIBUTIONS BASED ON A PERCENTAGE OF EXECUTIVE BASE SALARY AND, DEPENDING ON THE PLAN, ARE SUBJECT TO EITHER A THREE YEAR, AGE 59 1/2 OR A FIVE YEAR, AGE 65 VESTING SCHEDULE. UNTIL THE EXECUTIVE PROVIDES THESE SUBSTANTIAL FUTURE SERVICES, THESE SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT CONTRIBUTIONS ARE AT RISK, AND WILL BE FORFEITED IF THE EXECUTIVE LEAVES THE ORGANIZATION BEFORE REACHING HER OR HIS VESTING DATE. THE SUPPLEMENTAL RETIREMENT CONTRIBUTIONS ARE INCLUDED IN COLUMN (C) AS A NONTAXABLE BENEFIT IN THE YEAR THE CONTRIBUTION IS CREDITED TO THE EXECUTIVE'S ACCOUNT, AND ARE INCLUDED AGAIN ON THE FORM 990 IN COLUMN (B)(III) IF AND WHEN THE AMOUNT BECOMES VESTED IN A FUTURE YEAR, AS THE FORM 990 REQUIRES. NO INDIVIDUALS RECEIVED A PAYOUT DURING THE CURRENT YEAR.

NON-FIXED PAYMENTS THE PROVIDENCE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE (OF THE BOARD) HAS APPROVED AN EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION PHILOSOPHY THAT CLOSELY TIES AN EXECUTIVE'S COMPENSATION TO PERFORMANCE BOTH THE PERFORMANCE OF THE ORGANIZATION AND THE PERFORMANCE OF THE EXECUTIVE. THERE IS NO GUARANTEE THAT THIS PART OF A LEADER'S COMPENSATION WILL BE PAID IF THE PERFORMANCE OF THE ORGANIZATION OR OF THE INDIVIDUAL DOES NOT MEET THE PERFORMANCE STANDARDS FOR PAYMENT, NO PERFORMANCE-BASED PAYMENT IS MADE. THIS APPROACH IS REFLECTED IN PROVIDENCE'S LEADERSHIP ANNUAL INCENTIVE PLAN, WHICH IS A PERFORMANCE-BASED ANNUAL INCENTIVE PLAN THAT AFFORDS PARTICIPATING EXECUTIVES THE OPPORTUNITY TO EARN "AT RISK" COMPENSATION THROUGH PERFORMANCE AGAINST VERY CHALLENGING GOALS. PAYOUTS WILL BE AWARDED BASED ON GOALS RELATED TO STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES, FISCAL STEWARDSHIP AND QUALITY OF CARE THESE GOALS ARE SET BEFORE THE YEAR BEGINS AND ARE VERY CHALLENGING. THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE REVIEWS AND APPROVES EACH YEAR'S PERFORMANCE GOALS TO MAKE SURE THEY ARE SUFFICIENTLY CHALLENGING, AND TO MAKE SURE THE GOALS ARE DESIGNED TO HELP PROVIDENCE MEET ITS MISSION AND STRATEGIC PURPOSES. EACH YEAR THE PSJH BOARD EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE REVIEWS THE INCENTIVE PERFORMANCE AND MUST CERTIFY THE ACHIEVEMENT OF PERFORMANCE GOALS BEFORE ANY AWARDS ARE PAID OUT. WHEN REVIEWING AND APPROVING TOTAL COMPENSATION FOR EXECUTIVES, THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE INCLUDES INCENTIVE AWARDS, TO MAKE SURE THAT COMPENSATION IS REASONABLE AND WELL-SUPPORTED BY MARKET DATA. THE COMMITTEE CONSISTS ONLY OF DIRECTORS WHO ARE FREE OF CONFLICTS OF INTEREST, AND THE COMMITTEE RELIES ON MARKET SURVEY DATA GATHERED BY AN INDEPENDENT CONSULTANT. THE COMMITTEE CONDUCTS THIS REVIEW AND APPROVAL PROCESS IN A MANNER THAT IS IN ACCORDANCE WITH IRS REQUIREMENTS FOR COMPENSATION OF TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATION LEADERS, AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE BEST GOVERNANCE PRACTICES IN THE INDUSTRY.

THE AMOUNT PAID FOR COMMERCIAL CAR SERVICES IS NOT INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S TAXABLE WAGES AS THE CAR SERVICE WAS USED ONLY TO CONDUCT UNIVERSITY BUSINESS. FROM TIME TO TIME, THE UNIVERSITY MAY PROVIDE CERTAIN PAYMENTS THAT HAVE BEEN GROSSED-UP FOR TAX PURPOSES. FOR CALENDAR YEAR 2019, LYNNE ROSANSKY WAS THE ONLY INDIVIDUAL TO HAVE SUCH A PAYMENT. THIS AMOUNT IS INCLUDED IN HER TAXABLE INCOME. THE UNIVERSITY WILL OCCASIONALLY APPROVE FIRST CLASS TRAVEL FOR TRUSTEES OR OFFICERS WHEN THE TRAVEL IS WITHIN THE GUIDELINES OF THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL POLICY. PART I, LINE 4A LYNNE ROSANSKY AND VALARIE FOX RECEIVED SEVERENCE PAYMENTS OF $176,631 AND $83,975, RESPECTIVELY, DURING THE YEAR. THESE PAYMENTS ARE INCLUDED IN THEIR OTHER REPORTABLE COMPENSATION IN PART II.

EXPLANATION OF PART II: THE NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN HAS A FORMAL PROCEDURE AND SIGN-OFF PROCESS FOR REVIEW OF EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION. PART I, LINE 3: COMPENSATION FOR THE CEO IS DETERMINED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE ORGANIZATION'S BOARD OF TRUSTEES. THE MEMBERS OF THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE ARE ALL INDEPENDENT VOTING MEMBERS OF THE ORGANIZATION'S GOVERNING BODY. THE CEO SERVES PURSUANT TO THE TERMS OF AN EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT WHICH WAS APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE AFTER RETAINING AN EXECUTIVE SEARCH FIRM. IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE TERMS OF THE EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT, THE CEO'S TOTAL COMPENSATION WAS COMPOSED OF A BASE SALARY OF 550,000, AND DEFERRED COMPENSATION OF 150,000, BOTH OF WHICH ARE PRIVATELY FUNDED. THE DEFERRED COMPENSATION WAS INTENDED TO SERVE AS A RETENTION INCENTIVE. THE CEO DOES NOT RECEIVE HOUSING OR A HOUSING ALLOWANCE. THE CEO BEGAN HER TENURE AT THE GARDEN ON JULY 1, 2018. PART II, LINE 2: THE DIRECTOR OF THE GARDEN ALSO SERVE PURSUANT TO THE TERMS OF AN EMPLOYMENT AGREEMENT. THE DIRECTOR'S COMPENSATION IS APPROVED BY THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE. THE ASSISTANT TREASURER AND DIRECTOR'S COMPENSATION WAS REVIEWED BY THE GARDEN'S COMPENSATION COMMITTEE, ALONG WITH APPROPRIATE COMPARABILITY DATA, AND WAS DETERMINED BY THE COMMITTEE TO BE REASONABLE. PART II, LINES 2 - 10: COMPENSATION FOR OTHER OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES IS BASED ON INSTITUTIONAL SALARY COMPARISONS CONDUCTED BY THE GARDEN'S HUMAN RESOURCES OFFICE, WHICH REVIEWS SALARIES PAID BY COMPARABLE ORGANIZATIONS TO THEIR OFFICERS AND KEY EMPLOYEES. THE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE PERIODICALLY REVIEWS THE COMPENSATION LEVELS OF THESE EMPLOYEES. MERIT INCREASES ARE BASED ON A FORMAL PERFORMANCE EVALUATION PROCESS AND APPROVED BY THE CEO.

THE UNIVERSITY'S TRAVEL AND EXPENSE POLICY ALLOWS FOR FIRST- AND BUSINESS-CLASS AIR TRAVEL IN CERTAIN CIRCUMSTANCES FOR UNIVERSITY OFFICERS. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDES ON-CAMPUS HOUSING FOR THE PRESIDENT. THE ESTIMATED VALUE OF THIS HOUSING IS $18,928. THE HOUSING VALUES ARE BASED UPON RESIDENCE HALL RATES CHARGED TO UNIVERSITY STUDENTS. THE HOUSING VALUE IS INCLUDED IN THE PRESIDENT'S COMPENSATION DISCLOSED IN PART VII OF THE FORM 990. THE UNIVERSITY PAYS FOR INITIATION FEES AND MONTHLY DUES FOR A MEMBERSHIP FOR THE PRESIDENT TO THE SCRANTON COUNTRY CLUB AND THE ANNUAL MEMBERSHIP FEES FOR THE VICE PRESIDENT OF STUDENT LIFE AT GLENMAURA NATIONAL GOLF CLUB OF MOOSIC, PA. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PAYS FOR A MEMBERSHIP AT HAMILTON FARM GOLF CLUB OF GLADSTONE, NJ. THESE THREE MEMBERSHIPS ARE USED BY SENIOR ADMINISTRATORS TO HOST MEETINGS WITH BUSINESS PARTNERS OF THE UNIVERSITY, BOARD OF TRUSTEES MEMBERS, POTENTIAL DONORS, AND FACULTY AND STAFF. MEMBERSHIP IN THESE CLUBS ALLOWS FOR RECIPROCAL USE OF OTHER RELATED VENUES WITHIN THE UNITED STATES. THESE RECIPROCAL AGREEMENTS ALLOW SENIOR ADMINISTRATION TO HOST QUALITY BUSINESS AND FUNDRAISING EVENTS OUTSIDE THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA. THE UNIVERSITY ALSO PAYS FOR PERSONAL ASSISTANT SERVICES FOR THE PRESIDENT.

THE EXECUTIVE COMPENSATION COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES REVIEWS APPROPRIATE ANALYSES AND STUDIES PREPARED BY THE HUMAN RESOURCES OFFICE OR EXTERNAL SOURCES TO AID IN EVALUATING COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS AND STRATEGIES TO ATTRACT AND RETAIN QUALIFIED PERSONNEL FOR SENIOR EXECUTIVE ADMINISTRATIVE POSITIONS. THE COMMITTEE ANNUALLY REVIEWS AND APPROVES COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS FOR SENIOR ADMINISTRATORS AND OFFICERS OF THE UNIVERSITY. THIS REVIEW INCLUDES COMPARABLE MARKET DATA FOR POSITIONS AT OTHER HIGHER EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS. THE COMMITTEE REPORTS TO THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES THE TOTAL COMPENSATION PAID TO THE UNIVERSITY'S PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENTS. THE COMMITTEE REVIEWS THE RECOMMENDATIONS OF, AND ADVISES THE PRESIDENT AS TO THE INDIVIDUAL EMPLOYMENT CONTRACTS THAT ARE ABOVE AND BEYOND THE SCOPE OF THE UNIVERSITY'S BASE COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS STRUCTURE.

TRAVEL AT ONE CLASS ABOVE COACH CLASS IS OCCASIONALLY USED, PRIMARILY FOR INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL, AND THE CLASS IS USUALLY BUSINESS CLASS. BUSINESS/FIRST CLASS AIR TRAVEL WAS PROVIDED TO THE PRESIDENT FOR CERTAIN INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL. THE UNIVERSITY PROVIDED A HOUSE FOR THE PRESIDENT WHICH IS A NONTAXABLE WORKING CONDITION FRINGE BENEFIT SINCE HIS CONTRACT REQUIRES HIM TO RESIDE IN THE HOUSE ON THE UNIVERSITY CAMPUS. TAX INDEMNIFICATION OR GROSS-UP PAYMENTS ARE ONLY MADE FOR OCCASIONAL BONUS PAYMENTS AND REQUIRE APPROVAL BY THE PRESIDENT. THESE PAYMENTS ARE MADE IN ACCORDANCE WITH GENERAL UNIVERSITY COMPENSATION POLICIES. THE UNIVERSITY PAID CERTAIN SOCIAL CLUBS DUES AND INITIATION FEES FOR ONE OF ITS KEY EMPLOYEES. THIS BENEFIT WAS REPORTED AS TAXABLE COMPENSATION TO THE KEY EMPLOYEE.

NON-FIXED PAYMENTS WERE MADE TO THE PRESIDENT AND VP OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT. THESE BONUS PAYMENTS WERE BASED ON SATISFACTION OF PERFORMANCE TARGETS. ANNUALY, A COMPENSATION COMMITTEE COMPRISED OF UNIVERSITY TRUSTEES RESEARCHES COMPARABLE INSTITUTIONS' PRESIDENTIAL COMPENSATION AND SOLICITS INPUT FROM THE TRUSTEES ON THE INCUMBENT'S PERFORMANCE. IT THEN RECOMMENDS COMPENSATION (BASE SALARY AND BONUS, IF ANY) FOR THE COMING YEAR TO THE EXECUTIVE COMMITTEE OF THE BOARD, WHICH IS THE APPROVING AUTHORITY ON BEHALF OF THE BOARD. THE BONUS OF THE VP OF INSTITUTIONAL ADVANCEMENT WAS APPROVED BY THE PRESIDENT. DURING 2019, THE UNIVERSITY ALSO AWARDED BONUSES TO VARIOUS OTHER FACULTY AND STAFF, INCLUDING CERTAIN INDIVIDUALS LISTED ON SCHEDULE J. THESE BONUS PAYMENTS WERE DETERMINED BY HUMAN RESOURCES IN COLLABORATION WITH THE IMMEDIATE SUPERVISORS OF THE EMPLOYEES.
